title: 115_hr2831
content: The "Maritime Security Coordination Improvement Act" requires the Secretary to submit updates on the strategic plan for enhancing international supply chain security every three years. Additionally, it includes provisions for the Container Security Initiative. SEC. 3 of the Border and Maritime Security Coordination Improvement Act amends section 205 of the Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006. It changes the timeline for certain provisions and reorganizes subparagraphs. SEC. 4 addresses cybersecurity at ports. The Border and Maritime Security Coordination Improvement Act amends cybersecurity provisions to enhance maritime security activities, including facilitating information sharing on cybersecurity risks and incidents to address port-specific vulnerabilities. The Border and Maritime Security Coordination Improvement Act is amending cybersecurity provisions to address cybersecurity risks and incidents in maritime security activities, including prevention, management, and response to such threats. SEC. 5. Facility inspection intervals are amended to verify the effectiveness of security plans annually and as needed. SEC. 6. Recognition of other countries' trusted shipper programs is addressed in the Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006. SEC. 218 of the Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 addresses the recognition of other countries' trusted shipper programs. The Secretary must notify congressional committees before signing an arrangement with a foreign government for mutual recognition of supply chain security practices. The foreign government's supply chain security program must provide comparable security as C-TPAT. SEC. 7. UPDATES OF MARITIME OPERATIONS COORDINATION PLAN. This section amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 by adding a new section for updates of the Maritime Operations Coordination Plan. The Secretary must submit a maritime operations coordination plan every 180 days to specific committees, updating the plan released in July 2011 and focusing on coordination, integration, and joint awareness efforts for maritime security missions. The Secretary is responsible for maritime homeland security missions, including maintaining information sharing and intelligence integration with various levels of government and the private sector, cooperation with other agencies, and working within national and Department maritime security guidance. The Coast Guard is responsible for maritime homeland security missions, including maintaining information sharing and intelligence integration with various levels of government and the private sector. Additionally, there is an evaluation of Coast Guard deployable specialized forces. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to relevant committees assessing the state of the Coast Guard's Deployable Specialized Forces (DSF), including cost analysis, personnel numbers, and unit totals for the past three fiscal years. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report assessing the state of the Coast Guard's Deployable Specialized Forces (DSF), including unit totals, operations conducted, and distribution analysis. The Deployable Specialized Forces (DSFs) of the Coast Guard are being reorganized to focus on counterdrug operations and counter-terrorism capabilities in major U.S. ports. A Deployable Specialized Force is defined as a unit that can quickly react to handle counter-drug, counter-terrorism, and anti-terrorism operations or other maritime threats. SEC. 9. COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS OF CO-LOCATING DHS ASSETS. The Secretary of Homeland Security must conduct a cost-benefit analysis for co-locating aviation and maritime assets of the Office of Air and Marine Operations with other Department of Homeland Security agencies within 45 miles. Factors to consider include enhanced cooperation from co-location and potential savings from shared maintenance and logistics facilities. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to conduct a cost-benefit analysis for co-locating aviation and maritime assets within 45 miles, considering factors like enhanced cooperation, potential savings from shared facilities, operational costs, moving costs, and infrastructure expenses. A report summarizing the analysis results must be submitted to relevant committees within one year of the enactment of the Act. The Senate must submit a report summarizing the results of the cost-benefit analysis and any planned actions based on the findings. SEC. 10. Repeal of interagency operational centers for port security and secure systems of transportation. Sections 70107A and 70116 of title 46, United States Code, are repealed. SEC. 11. Conforming and clerical amendments. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended by redesignating and striking various sections. Subsections in section 121 are also amended. Sections related to port security and transportation systems are repealed. Conforming and clerical amendments are made. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended by redesignating and striking various sections, including sections related to port security and transportation systems. Conforming and clerical amendments are made to the Act. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended by redesignating and striking various sections, including sections related to port security and transportation systems. Title I is amended by striking items relating to sections 105 through 110 and inserting new items. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended to include new provisions such as the prohibition of transportation security cards for certain felons, long-range vessel tracking, notice of arrival for foreign vessels on the Outer Continental Shelf, and enhanced crewmember identification. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended to include new provisions related to random searches of containers, work stoppages, threat assessment screening of port truck drivers, Border Patrol unit for United States Virgin Islands, and Center of Excellence for Maritime Domain Awareness. Additionally, there are updates on information sharing for supply chain security cooperation. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is amended to include provisions on homeland security grants, trucking security, air and marine operations, phaseout of vessels supporting oil and gas development, Coast Guard property in Portland, Maine, methamphetamine regulations, and protection of health and safety during disasters. Title 46 is also updated by removing items relating to specific sections.
